experience: You and Jarrett both know Mark Botticelli, Justin Copp, and 13 others
I never fly into cities after dark.
If I do because of delays I have a protocol I follow.
I never let  any men know my room number (not even male colleagues). If they need something they deliver it to the front desk and text me.
I request a new room if they announce my room number.
I never wait outside of a hotel (even to enjoy the sun) unless someone is with me.
If I don't have a business dinner I eat alone in my room.
I never tour strange cities alone.
I decline ALL drinks (that includes non alcoholic) sent to me by strangers.
I never share a ride with strangers.
I never sit in my car and do work on my phone.
I've been mocked, ridiculed and laughed at for my "rules".
I've had incidents where I quietly removed my heels because I thought I was going to need to run.
I've had to slide notes to request assistance to help myself elegantly slide out of situations that turned unsafe.
I've had to keep my elbows out and head down on more than one occasion.
I listened to horror stories that happened directly to friends.
It's stupid that I need these rules but I created these rules because of my experiences and those of my dearest friends
My #stupidrules are worth it because my safety is worth it.
How to Help Those Affected by the Northern California Fires - Indigenous
Have you ever been asked by a recruiter, what's your current salary or what are you looking to make?
What is it about this question that is SO difficult to answer? Why do I hear story after story of people who simply FAIL to answer this question appropriately?

I would love nothing more than to have a real conversation on this forum (LinkedIn) about why so many fret over this question - especially our MILITARY VETERANS. Yes, our veterans seem to have the most difficult time answering this question.

I recently took a call from a veteran who was frustrated over the fact that while during his interview, when asked "how much are you looking to make?" he didn't know what to say. He said he just froze and didn't know how to answer.

Seriously, come on, this is NOT that difficult to do - especially with the power of the INTERNET! For anyone who is going through the interview process (and forgive me if this seems elementary), please take a moment and do your RESEARCH!!!!
I STRONGLY encourage you to visit the following resources before going on your next interview:
Richard Smith, former Equifax CEO essentially blames one man for the 140+ million accounts that were breached this year.
In my opinion, if you can't take the entire blame for your team's actions or inactions, you don't belong as a leader of said team.

Jarrett is one of the best managers I have ever experienced in my life.  He not only is truly passionate about the company he works for but also deeply cares for his employees.  Jarrett is very dedicated as well as efficient at the choices he makes.  He loves doing the best job he can possibly do and won't give up till its done. He is great at whatever work he does and is very intelligent. Jarrett would be a great asset to any company and I would be honored to work under him again any time.

Isaac encompasses all meanings what a skilled programmer looks like. His ability to jump from one programming language to the next is just one illustration of how talented he really is. Java, PHP, ASP.NET, he's not afraid to get out of his comfort zone; that is if he has one! He's extremely detailed oriented, solid problem solver, and gets the job done. Isaac's the kind of guy who develops in his off hours because he loves to do it, not because he has to. Any company would be so fortunate to have him.

When Tim originally came in to interview for the position he held at BagSelect (Quintactic, LLC), he immediately stood out. He wasn't just looking for a job to "simply have a job", but rather he researched what our company was about and had questions, honest, personal input.After hiring Tim, we were able to increase his workload exponentially as he was quick to learn, quick to get the job done, and never hesitate about making smart decisions.Tim is a great person in the workplace and out. Having had Tim work for us at BagSelect.com, we had the opportunity to really get to know Tim and his great character.

summary: A fearless Senior Software Developer with an eye for usability and design; and the ability to produce functional and scalable, mission-critical web applications.Overall, I've been developing on the web for over 16 years (12 years professionally). I'm very experienced with a wide variety of modern and legacy frameworks, CMSs, and languages including: Laravel 5, Symfony 2/3,  Wordpress, Magento, CraftCMS, Yii, Zend Framework, Kohana 3.0+, and ExpressionEngine, PHP5, HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript (Objected Oriented), jQuery, JSON, XML, AJAX, Grunt, Backbone.js, Require.js, Git, SASS, and more. I also have previous experience with Objective C, Java, Coldfusion, and ASP.NET (C#). Lastly, I've deployed and managed servers/instances on an array of cloud based hosting solutions including Amazon Web Services (AWS), EngineYard, and Rackspace.In addition to my web development experience, I have approximately 10 years of UX and UX methodology experience. I also regularly follow current UI design principles and best practices; and am very comfortable creating usability wireframes, mockups, and workflows.
name: Jarrett Barnett
title: Senior PHP Software & DevOps Engineer
